<description type="note">Preliminaries and editorial matter including introduction and glossary omitted.<lb/>The following plays have been taken from this source:<lb/>Source texts incomplete</description>
Genre: English mystery and miracle plays.

XI. THE HOSEERS. The departure of the Israelites from Egypt, the ten plagues, and the passage of the Red Sea. Square brackets represent sections of text unclear or absent in the original and supplied by the current editor
PERSONS OF THE PLAY. Rex Pharao. Deus. Moyses. Primus et secundus Consoles (i.e. king's officers). Primus, secundus et tertius pueri (i.e. Jews). Primus et secundus Egyptii.

Scene I, Pharaoh's court. 1. Rex. O pees, I bidde Ã¾at noman passe, But kepe Ã¾e cours Ã¾at I comaunde, And takes gud heede to hym Ã¾at hasse Youre liff all haly in his hande. Kyng Pharo my fadir was, And led Ã¾e lordshippe of this lande, I am hys hayre as elde will asse, Euere in his steede to styrre and stande. All Egippe is myne awne, To lede aftir my lawe, I will my myght be knawen, And honnoured als it awe. 2. Ther-fore als Kyng I commaunde pees To all Ã¾e pepill of Ã¾is Empire, That noman putte hym fourthe in prees, But Ã¾at will do als we desire. And of youre sawes I rede you sees, And sesse to me, youre sufferayne sire, That most youre comforte may encrese, And at my liste lose liffe and lyre. i Cons. My lorde, yf any were Ãat walde not wirke youre will, And we wist whilke thay were, Ful sone we sall Ã¾aym spill. 3. Rex. Thurgh-oute my kyngdome wolde I kenn, And konne tham thanke Ã¾at couthe me telle, If any wer so weryd Ã¾en That wolde aught fande owre forse to fell. ii Con. My lorde, Ã¾ar are a maner of men, That mustirs grete maistris Ã¾am emell, The Jewes Ã¾at wonnes here in Jessen And er named the childir of Israell. They multyplye so faste, Ãat suthly we suppose Thay are like, and they laste, Yowre lordshippe for to lose. 4. Rex. Why, devill, what gawdes haue they begonne? Er Ã¾ai of myght to make a frayse? i Cons. Tho felons folke, Sir, first was fonn In kyng Pharo ?oure fadyr dayse; Thay come of Joseph, Jacob sonn, That was a prince worthy to prayse, And sithen in ryste furthe are they run, Now ar they like to lose our layse. Thay sall confounde vs clene, Bot if Ã¾ai sonner sese. Rex. What devill ever may it mene, Ãat they so fast encrese? 5. ii Cons. Howe they encrese, full wele we kenn, Als oure elders be-fore vs fande, Thay were talde but sexty and ten Whan Ã¾ei enterd in to Ã¾is lande. Sithen haue they soionerd here in Jessen Foure houndereth ?ere, Ã¾is we warande, Now are they noumbered of myghty men, Wele more Ã¾an thre hundereth thowsande, With-owten wiffe and childe, And herdes Ã¾at kepes ther fee. Rex. So myght we be bygillid, But certis Ã¾at sall noght be, 6. For with qwantise we sall Ã¾am qwelle Ãat Ã¾ei sall no farrar sprede. i Cons. Lorde, we have herde oure ffadres telle, Howe clerkis, Ã¾at ful wele couthe rede, Saide, a man shulde wax Ã¾am emell, That suld for-do vs and owre dede. Rex. Fy on Ã¾am! to Ã¾e devell of helle! Swilke destanye sall we noght drede. We sall make mydwayes to spille Ã¾am, Whenne oure Ebrewes are borne, All Ã¾at are mankynde to kille Ã¾am, So sall they sone be lorne. 7. For of the other haue I non awe, Swilke bondage sall we to Ã¾am bede, To dyke and delfe, beere and drawe, And do all swilke vn-honest dede. Ãus sall Ã¾e laddis be holden lawe, Als losellis ever thaire lyff to leede. ii Con. Certis, lorde, Ã¾is is a sotell sawe, So sall Ã¾e folke no farrar sprede. Rex. Yaa! helpes to halde Ã¾am doune, Ãat we no fantnyse fynde. i Cons. Lorde, we sall ever be bowne, In bondage Ã¾am to bynde.

Scene II, near Mount Sinai. 8. Moyses. Grete god! Ãat all Ã¾is grounde be-gan, And governes euere in gud degree, That made me Moyses vn-to man, And saued me sythen out of Ã¾e see. Kyng Pharo he comaunded Ã¾an So Ã¾at no sonnes shulde saued be, Agayns his wille away I wan, Thus has god shewed his myght in me. Nowe am I here to kepe, Sett vndir synay syde, The bisshoppe Jetro schepe, So bettir bute to bide. [Sees the burning bush. 9. A! mercy, god, mekill is thy myght, What man may of thy meruayles mene, I se ?ondyr a ful selcouth syght, Wher-of be-for no synge was seene. A busk I se yondir brennand bright, And Ã¾e leues last ay in like grene, If it be werke of worldly wight, I will go witte with-owten wene. Deus. Moyses! come noght to nere, Bot stille in Ã¾at stede dwelle, And take hede to me here, And tente what I Ã¾e telle. 10. I am thy lorde, with-outyn lak, To lengh Ã¾i liffe euen as me list, And the same god Ã¾at som tyme spak Vn-to thyne elders als Ã¾ei wiste; But Abraham and Ysaac, And Jacob, saide I, suld be bliste, And multyplye and Ã¾am to mak, So Ã¾at Ã¾er seede shulde noght be myste. And nowe kyng Pharo, Fuls Ã¾are childir ful faste If I suffir hym soo, Ãare seede shulde sone be past. 11. Go, make Ã¾e message haue I mende To hym Ã¾at Ã¾am so harmed hase, Go, warne hym with wordes hende, So Ã¾at he lette my pepull passe, That they to wildirnesse may wende, And wirshippe me als whilom was. And yf he lenger gar them lende, His sange ful sone sall be, âallas!â Moyses. A! lord syth, with thy leue, Ãat lynage loves me noght, Gladly they walde me greve, And I slyke boodword brought. 12. Ther-fore lord, late sum othir fraste Ãat hase more forse Ã¾am for to feere. Deus. Moyses, be noght a-baste, My bidding baldely to bere, If thai with wrang ought walde Ã¾e wrayste Owte of all wothis I sall Ã¾e were. Moyses. We! lord, Ã¾ai wil noght to me trayste, For al the othes Ã¾at I may swere. To neven slyke note of newe To folke of wykkyd will, With-outen taken trewe, They will noght take tente Ã¾er-till. 13. Deus. And if they will noght vndirstande, Ne take heede how I haue Ã¾e sente, Before the kyng cast downe thy wande, & it sall seme as a serpent. Sithen take the tayle in thy hande, And hardely vppe Ã¾ou itt hente, In the firste state als Ã¾ou it fande. So sall it turne be myn entent. Hyde thy hande in thy barme, And serpent it sall be like, Sithen hale with-outen harme, Ãi syngnes sall be slyke. 14. And if he wil not suffre than My pepull for to passe in pees, I sall send vengeaunce ix or x., To sewe hym sararre, or I sesse. Bot Ã¾e Jewes Ã¾at wonnes in Jessen Sall no?t be merked with Ã¾at messe, Als lange als Ã¾ai my lawes will kenne Ãer comfort sal I euere encresse. Moyses. A! lorde, lovyd be thy wille, Ãat makes thy folke so free, I sall tell Ã¾am vn-till Als Ã¾ou telles vn-to me. 15. But to the kyng, lorde, whan I come, And he ask me what is thy name, And I stande stille Ã¾an, defe and dum, How sall I be withouten blame? Deus. I saie Ã¾us, ego sum qui sum, I am he Ã¾at I am the same, And if Ã¾ou myght not meve ne mum, I sall Ã¾e saffe fro synne & shame. Moyses. I vndirstande Ã¾is thyng, With all Ã¾e myght in me. Deus. Be bolde in my blissyng, Thy belde ay sall I be. 16. Moyses. A! lorde of lyffe, lere me my layre, Ãat I Ã¾ere tales may trewly tell, Vn-to my frendis nowe will I fayre, Ãe chosen childre of Israell. To telle Ã¾am comforte of ther care, And of Ã¾ere daunger Ã¾at Ã¾ei in dwell.

Scene III, Moses and the Hebrews. [Moses]. God mayntayne you & me euermare, And mekill myrthe be you emell. i puer. A! Moyses, maistir dere, Oure myrthe is al mornyng, We are harde halden here Als carls vndir Ã¾e kyng. 17. ii puer. Moyses, we may mourne and myne, Ãer is no man vs myrÃ¾es mase, And sen we come al of a kynne, Ken vs som comforte in Ã¾is case. Moyses. Beeths of youre mornyng blyne, God wil defende you of your fays, Oute of Ã¾is woo he will you wynne, To plese hym in more plener place. I sall carpe to Ã¾e kyng, And fande to make you free. iii puer. God sende vs gud tythyngis, And all may with you be.

Scene IV, At Pharaoh's court. 18. Moyses. Kyng Pharo! to me take tent! Rex. Why, what tydyngis can Ã¾ou tell? Moyses. Fro god of heuen Ã¾us am I sente, To fecche his folke of Israell, To wildirnesse he walde thei wente. Rex. ?aa! wende Ã¾ou to Ã¾e devell of hell, I make no force howe Ã¾ou has mente, For in my daunger sall Ã¾ei dwelle. And faytour, for thy sake, Ãei sall be putte to pyne. Moyses. Ãanne will god vengeaunce take On Ã¾e and on al Ã¾yne. 19. Rex. Fy on the! ladde, oute of my lande! Wenes Ã¾ou with wiles to lose oure laye? Where is Ã¾is warlowe with his wande, Ãat wolde Ã¾us wynne oure folke away? ii Cons. It is Moyses, we wele warrand, Agayne al Egipte is he ay. Youre fadir grete faute in hym fande, Nowe will he marre you if he may. Rex. Nay, nay, Ã¾at daunce is done, Ãat lordan leryd ouere late. Moyses. God biddis Ã¾e graunte my bone, And late me go my gate. 20. Rex. Biddis god me? fals lurdayne, Ã¾ou lyes; What takyn talde he, toke Ã¾ou tent? Moyses. ?aa! sir, he saide Ã¾ou suld despise Botht me & all his comaundement. In thy presence kast on this wise My wande he bad by his assent, And Ã¾at Ã¾ou shulde Ã¾e wele avise, Howe it shulde turne to a serpent. And in his haly name, Here sal I ley it downe, Loo! ser, se her Ã¾e same. Rex. A! dogg! Ã¾e deuyll Ã¾e drowne! 21. Moyses. He saide Ã¾at I shulde take Ã¾e tayle, So for to proue his poure playne, And sone he saide it shuld not fayle For to turne a wande agayne. Loo! sir, be-halde! Rex. Hopp illa hayle! Now certis Ã¾is is a sotill swayne. But Ã¾is boyes sall byde here in oure bayle, For all Ã¾air gaudis sall noght Ã¾am gayne; Bot warse, both morne and none, Sall Ã¾ei fare for thy sake. Moyses. God sende sum vengeaunce sone, And on Ã¾i werke take wrake. [Moses retires: enter Egyptians. 22. i Egip. Allas! allas! Ã¾is lande is lorne, On lif we may no lenger lende. ii Egip. So grete myscheffe is made sen morne, Ãer may no medycyne vs amende. Cons. Sir kyng, we banne Ã¾at we wer borne, Oure blisse is all with bales blende. Rex. Why crys you swa, laddis? liste you scorne? i Egip. Sir kyng, slyk care was neuere kende. Oure watir Ã¾at was ordand To men and beestis fudde, Thurghoute al Egipte lande Is turned to rede blude; 23. Full vgly and ful ill is it, Ãat was ful faire and fresshe before. Rex. This is grete wondir for to witte, Of all Ã¾e werkis Ã¾at ever wore. ii Egip. Nay, lorde, Ã¾er is anothir ?itt, That sodenly sewes vs ful sore, For tadys and frosshis we may not flitte, Thare venym loses lesse and more. i Egip. Lorde, grete myses bothe morn and none Bytis vs full bittirlye, And we hope al by done By moyses, oure enemye. 24. i Cons. Lord, whills we with Ã¾is menyhe meve, Mon never myrthe be vs emange. Rex. Go, saie we salle no lenger greve; [Aside. But Ã¾ai sall neuere Ã¾e tytar gang. ii Egip. Moyses, my lord has grauntyd leve At lede thy folke to likyng lande, So Ã¾at we mende of oure myscheue. Moyses. I wate ful wele Ã¾ar wordes er wrang, That sall ful sone be sene, For hardely I hym heete And he of malice mene. Mo mervaylles mon he mett. 25. i Egip. Lorde, allas! for dule we dye, [To the king. We dar not loke oute at no dore. Rex. What deuyll ayles yow so to crye? ii Egip. We fare nowe werre Ã¾an euere we fure. Grete loppis ouere all Ã¾is lande Ã¾ei flye, That with bytyng makis mekill blure. i Egip. Lorde, oure beestis lyes dede and dry, Als wele on myddyng als on more; Both oxe, horse, and asse, Fallis dede doune sodanly. Rex. Ther-of no man harme has Halfe so mekill as I. 26. ii Cons. ?is, lorde, poure men has mekill woo To see Ã¾er catell be out cast, The Jewes in Jessen faren no?t soo, They haue al likyng in-to last. Rex. Go, saie we giffe Ã¾am leue to goo To tyme there parellis be ouer past; [Aside. But, or thay flitte over farre vs froo, We sall garre feste Ã¾am foure so fast. ii Egip. Moyses, my lord giffis leue Thy men for to remewe. Moyses. He mon haue more mischeff But if his tales be trewe. 27. i Egip. We! lorde, we may not lede this liffe. Rex. Why! is ther greuance growen agayne? ii Egip. Swilke pou[d]re, lord, a-pon vs dryffe, That whare it bettis it makis a blayne. i Egip. Like mesellis makis it man and wyffe; Sythen ar they hurte with hayle and rayne, Oure wynes in mountaynes may not thryve, So ar they threst and thondour slayne. Rex. How do thay in Jessen; Ãe Jewes, can ?e aught say? ii Egip. Ãis care nothyng they ken, Ãay fele no such affray. 28. Rex. No, devill! and sitte they so in pees? And we ilke day in doute and drede. i Egip. My lorde, Ã¾is care will euere encrese Tille Moyses have leve Ã¾am to lede. i Cons. Lorde, war they wente Ã¾an walde it sese, So shuld we save vs and oure seede, Ellis be we lorne; Ã¾is is no lese. Rex. Late hym do fourth! Ã¾e devill hym spede! For his folke sall no ferre Yf he go welland woode. ii Cons. Ãan will itt sone be warre, ?it war bettir Ã¾ai ?oode. 29. ii Egip. We! lorde, new harme is comon to hande. Rex. No! devill! will itt no bettir be? i Egip. Wilde wormes is laide ouere al this lande, Ãai leve no frute ne floure on tree; Agayne Ã¾at storme may no thyng stande. ii Egip. Lord, ther is more myscheff thynke me, And thre daies hase itt bene durand, So myrke Ã¾at non myght othir see. i Egip. My lorde, grete pestelence Is like ful lange to last. Rex. Owe! come Ã¾at in oure presence? Than is oure pride al past. 30. ii Egip. My lorde, Ã¾is vengeaunce lastis lange, And mon till Moyses haue his bone. i Cons. Lorde, late Ã¾am wende, els wirke [we] wrang, It may not helpe to hover na hone. Rex. Go, saie we graunte Ã¾am leue to gange, In the devill way, sen itt bus be done, For so may fall we sall Ã¾am fang, And marre Ã¾am or to-morne at none. i Egip. Moyses, my lorde has saide, Ãou sall haue passage playne. Moyses. And to passe am I paied, My frendes, bees nowe fayne; 31. For at oure will now sall we wende, In lande of lykyng for to lende. i puer. Kyng Pharo, that felowns fende, Will haue grete care fro this be kende, Than will he schappe hym vs to shende, And sone his Ooste aftir vs sende. Moyses. Beis noght aferde, god is youre frende, Fro alle oure fooes he will vs fende. Ãarfore comes furthe with me, Haves done, and drede yow noght. ii puer. My lorde, loved mott Ã¾ou bee, Ãat Ã¾us fro bale has brought. 32. iii puer. Swilke frenshippe never before we fande. But in Ã¾is faire defautys may fall, Ãe rede see is ryght nere at hande, Ãer bus vs bide to we be thrall. Moyses. I sall make vs way with my wande, For god hase sayde he saue vs sall; On aythir syde Ã¾e see sall stande, Tille we be wente, right as a wall. Therfore have ?e no drede, But faynde ay god to plese. i puer. Ãat lorde to lande vs lede, Now wende we all at esse. 33. i Egip. Kyng Pharro, ther folke er gane. Rex. Howe nowe! es ther any noyes of newe? ii Egip. The Ebrowes er wente ilkone. Rex. Now sais Ã¾ou Ã¾at? i Egip. Ãer talis er trewe. Rex. Horse harneys tyte, Ã¾at Ã¾ei be tane, Ãis ryott radly sall Ã¾am rewe, We sall not sese or they be slone, For to Ã¾ese we sall Ã¾am sew. Do charge oure charyottis swithe, And frekly folowes me. ii Egip. My lorde we are full blithe, At youre biddyng to be. 34. ii Cons. Lorde, to youre biddyng we er boune, Owre bodies baldely for to bede, We sall noght byde, but dyng Ã¾am doune, Tylle all be dede, with-outen drede. Rex. Hefe vppe youre hartis ay to Mahownde, He will be nere vs in oure nede.

Scene V, The Red Sea. Owte! ay herrowe! devill, I drowne! i Egip. Allas! we dye, for alle our dede. i puer. Now ar we wonne fra waa, and saued oute of Ã¾e see. Cantemus domino, to god a sange synge wee. Finis.
